ASSISTANT SECRETARY
February 17, 1923
My dear Miss Carter:
div1.p:
On return to New York I find your letter of
February 10 and your father's letter of February 11
awaiting me. What we have done in the way of provid-
ing a small compensation for the work which your father
is doing is merely an act of simple justice. We could
really never pay him adequately for the work for he is
doing that which no other living man could do so well.
After all he is contributing from the wealth of his ex-
perience to the great cause in which we are all so deep-
ly interested. In addition to the work which is being
accomplished, we are having the great satisfaction of
cooperating with him in this undertaking.

In this connection I wish to assure you that
we are not forgetful of the part which you too are play-
ing in it. When I talked with Surgeon General Cumming
about the legal difficulties that might be involved
Miss Laura Armistead Carter February 17, 1923 2
in compensating your father and when he had agreed to have
the matter looked into with great care, he said if it should
develop that we could not compensate your father directly,
we could pay it to you; that you and your father were really
partners in this work any way. The terms of warm appreciation
in which he referred to you greatly increased my appreciation
of him.

Let me take this occasion to thank you very hear-
tily for the volume which you handed me just as I was leav-
ing your home at the time of my last visit. I read this on
the train with keenest interest and satisfaction. It revealed
a talent which I did not know you possessed. You must not
let even the yellow fever work interfere with your own per-
sonal writing. I wish to thank you particularly for what you
had written on the fly-leaf.

With warmest personal regards to yourself and your
father,
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Wickliffe Rose. Miss Laura Armistead Carter
